answer: The Heiress (1947 play) tells of the efforts of a brilliant and wealthy surgeon to find a suitable candidate for his daughter's hand in marriage. The work was adapted as a film of the same title in 1949. The play is based on the 1880 novel Washington Square. In a New York society, a doctor finds it difficult to get his daughter, an heiress, to agree to marriage. Her shy disposition and refusal to meet men he has found for her to meet causes him to grow angry. He attempts to find a young person who would match with her, only to find the one match he wanted to be engaged. A former suitor of hers returns to New York, having made a fortune in the South. However, he comes to meet the daughter only for his interest in the fortune. Dr. A. comes into conflict with himself, the daughter, and the man who loves his daughter for her money, while the daughter grows more and more in love with the fortune seeker. Finally, after a series of events in which the fortune seeker reveals his true intentions, Dr. A. gives the daughter and the fortune seeker an ultimatum that will either give them their marriage or give them a break up.

answer: The Reader (2008 film) The Reader is a 2008 British-German drama film directed by Stephen Daldry and written by David Hare, based on the 1995 German novel of the same name by Bernhard Schlink. answer: Baahubali: The Beginning (transl. The One with the Strong Arms: The Beginning) is a 2015 Indian epic fantasy film directed and co-produced by S. S. Rajamouli. It is the first film in the Baahubali franchise. The other parts of the franchise are Baahubali 2: The Conclusion (2017) and Baahubali: Before the Beginning (TBA). The film was produced on a budget of Rs 175 cr INR (equivalent to US$ 28.83 million in 2015). The film's bilingual premieres in both Telugu and Tamil were separately held at the Madras and Devi theatres in Chennai on 9 July 2015 and 10 July 2015 respectively. It was the first Indian film to be released in 4K High Definition format. It was the highest grossing film in India and garnered the third-highest grossing Indian film by worldwide standards at that time.

answer: Newspaper is a periodical publication containing printed, illustrated, or digital news and/or opinions. The earliest printed newspaper was done in 1507 in Venice. It was discovered by Johannes Gutenberg in 1436. The earliest evidence of news newspapers date to 500's BC. Modern newspapers are usually issued daily or weekly, on a feudal basis. The news may be distributed in hard copy, e-paper, on the Internet, or may be available as an electronic audiovisual display. News (and its delivery) may also be actively distributed, as in the case of an infopod, a similar device used by a fictional mid-21st century society in the television series Max Headroom to disseminate news to the general public. Also (more recently) known as the "hard copy". This has not replaced the "hard copy" due to the inherent distrust of electronic sources of information and the lack of quality control in classic, hard-copy media.

Produced by Justin Meldal-Johnsen, Paramore (album) was recorded from October 2012 to February 2013 at Rock Falcon studio in Franklin, Tennessee. It is the only album to feature original songs written without former members Josh Farro and Zac Farro. The album was reissued in July of that year, featuring the hit song "Ain't It Fun", which won the band their first Grammy award. It was produced by American production trio The Cavalry.

answer: Mango, the fruiting tree of the genus Mangifera, contains one of the richest combinations of nutrients that are useful to the human body. The edible part, fruit or the mangoes, contain a large variety of phyto nutrients, vitamins, minerals and anti-oxidants required for normal growth metabolism and wellness. The sweet, succulent juicy mango is a rich source of Vitamin A, Vitamin C, Vitamin B 6 and Vitamin B 12. Mango provides a good amount of potassium, magnesium, phosphorus, calcium, sodium and high levels of dietary fiber. Fresh mango contains fats, carbohydrates, protein and a small amount of alkaloids. According to the USDA, 500 mg of mango pulp and 3 mango seeds provide just 170 calories, making it low in calories. The vitamin minerals and other phyto-nutrients like pectin soluble fiber, beta-carotene, alpha carotene and salts are excellent antioxidants. They provide good resistance to infections and protection for the body against infectious cough, cold and flu.

answer: Blue-ringed octopus (Hapalochlaena) is a genus of three octopus species, the only members of the genus Hapalochlaena. They live in the Pacific or Indian oceans, in shallow coral reefs, primarily from Cargodera to Micronesia. As adults they are 15–20 cm (5.9–7.9 in) in length, and weigh around 100 g (3.5 oz). They have a large, bulbous head; a thin, curved body; and small eyes located on the bulbous head. They have a row of small suckers located along the inside surfaces of both of the octopus's arms. answer: Conan O'Brien (born April 18, 1963) is an American comedian, writer, producer, and television host. answer: Jingle Bells" is one of the most popular American Christmas songs in the world. It was written by James Lord Pierpont (1822–1893) and published under the title "One Horse Open Sleigh" in the autumn of 1857. Even though it is commonly thought of as a modern Christmas song, it was actually copyrighted on September 16, 1857. Despite the publishing date, Pierpont's song was most likely written in Medford, Massachusetts, in 1850. Some area choirs still sing it, in Medford. "Jingle Bells" has been recorded by dozens of singers, the most popular being Bing Crosby's version.

answer: Bal Gangadhar Tilak (born Keshav Gangadhar Tilak; 23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920), was an Indian nationalist, social reformer, lawyer, journalist, actor, and an important Indian independence activist. answer: Doc Holliday, along with Billy the Kid and Big Nose Kate, is one of the few Western characters to earn more fame in the movies than in the real world. However, the real Holliday was actually far more interesting. An educated man, he earned a dental degree, but had to flee the South after taking part in a shooting in a saloon. Although he was dying of consumption, he made his way out West and took part in the gunfight at the Ok Corral, standing next to Wyatt Earp for a shootout against the Clanton gang. His life inspired many novels and movies, including John Wayne's first starring role in 1939's "Stagecoach" and Kirk Douglas' part in "Gunfight at the Okay Corral."

answer: Northeast megalopolis (sometimes referred to as BosWash) is a term for the most urbanized region in both the United States and Canada, or one of the most densely populated corridors in the world. It includes the cities along the Atlantic (Northeast) and the Continental (Southwest) seaboards from Boston to Washington, DC via New York City and Philadelphia. The term is used in particular for the region between Toronto, Boston and New York City (sometimes extended along I-95 as far south as Washington, DC). This area is home to approximately 54.4 million people as of 2016, more than a quarter of the U.S. population and a little over a tenth of the total population of NorthAmerica.

USER:
topic: National Council for Peace and Order
answer: National Council for Peace and Order is the military junta of Thailand after the coup of 22 Mai 2014. After the coup was successful the junta named itself National Council for Peace and Order and its leader as General Prayut Chan-o-cha. Although not explicitly declaring military rule, it controls government affairs via edict, and acts as de facto executive of the government. In June 2015, Gen Prayut lifted some martial law restrictions so that civilian government, parliament and constitutional monarchy could start functioning again to move towards the restoration of democracy, but retaining control of the government.

answer: Daniel Craig is an English actor. Craig has an accent typical of the East Midlands, as well as an accent common to the North West of England. The film transitions into and out of Constantine's journey among the shades of the underworld.

USER:
answer: Republic of Ireland (Irish: Poblacht na hÉireann), also known as Ireland, is a sovereign state in north-western Europe, with a large island of the same name off the north-western coast of the European continent. It is the second-largest island on the island and the third-largest in Europe. The island is separated from mainland Great Britain by the Irish Sea and from mainland France by the English Channel. In the west, a narrow sea channel (the Strait of Dover) separates it from the island of Great Britain. Ireland has no land borders with other countries (although it is connected to Great Britain by the undersea tunnel), and it is the only European country that is not a physical part of continental Europe. Ireland has an area of 70,273 km², and a population of 6,497,955. Ireland comprises two geopolitical entities: the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The Republic, informally known as Ireland, covers five-sixths of the island. The Republic joined the European Economic Community, the forerunner of the European Union (EU), in 1973. It shares a close relationship with the United Kingdom as a member of the European Union and through a common membership of the Commonwealth of Nations. Northern Ireland is a small but culturally important part of the United Kingdom, covering one-sixth of the area of the island of Ireland. The republic is part of the European Union and the Euro zone.

answer: BRIT School (The British Record Industry Trust School) is a non-fee paying arts college, specialising in the performing arts, digital media and technology, which is situated in the grounds of Selhurst Park, next door to South Norwood railway station. USER:
answer: Social anxiety disorder, also known as social phobia, is an anxiety disorder in which a person has excessive and disabling fear or anxiety in social situations, but not in specific phobic contexts. These situations may include talking with or engaging in social communication with others, being observed or inhibiting his or her behavior because of perceived scrutiny, or in general performance situations. The disorder may be so severe that affected people go to great lengths to avoid certain types of social interaction. Some sources equate social anxiety disorder with shyness and reticence. However, in socially anxious individuals, the underlying anxiety is not necessarily a response to anything in particular, but an overwhelming worry, fear and expectation of disruption from the social environment.

answer: Azerbaijan is a country in the South Caucasus region of Eurasia at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Western Asia. answer: Trevor Berbick (21 August 1954 – 28 October 2006) was a Jamaican-born former boxer best known for taking Muhammad Ali's last career bout. Standing at 6 ft 2¾ in (190 cm) tall and weighing about 206 lb (93.4 kg), he had been a powerful fighter in his prime. One of his famous matches was his defeat of highly rated contender Marvis Frazier (son of former heavyweight champion Joe Frazier) at the age of twenty-eight in 1985. In addition, he had previously defeated Dwight Muhammad Qawi to win the vacant North American Boxing Council Continental America cruiserweight title in 1985. He was the first and only boxer to come out of the Caribbean to capture a portion of the world heavyweight championship (WBC belt).

answer: Laurence Olivier, Baron Olivier, OM (/oʊˈlɪviəə/; 22 May 1907 – 11 July 1989) was an English actor and director who, along with his contemporaries Ralph Richardson and John Gielgud, dominated the British stage of the mid-20th century. answer: Celtic F.C. (Celtic Football Club; Scottish Gaelic: Club Cheltìc) is a professional football club based in Glasgow, Scotland, which plays in the Scottish Premiership. The Celtic Football Club was founded in 1887 with the purpose of alleviating poverty in the immigrant Irish population in the East End of Glasgow.[3]The club's name was chosen with the intent and desire to avoid the word "Irish" in order to avoid any sectarian connotations, there have been a number of theories about the club's name. They may have been encouraged to choose a name that reflected their Irish and British heritage, or it may have been an attempt to shy away from the association with Ireland.

answer: Dodecanese refers to the group of twelve larger plus five smaller islands in the southeastern Aegean, off the coast of Asia Minor, and constituting the southeastern extension of the Hellenic archipelago. answer: Pat Riley (born Patrick James Riley on March 20, 1945) is an American professional basketball executive, and a former coach and player in the National Basketball Association (NBA). He has been the team president of the Miami Heat in the NBA since 1995 and head coach on two separate occasions (most recently head coach for the entire 2008–09 season). He previously, was the head coach of the Los Angeles Lakers and the New York Knicks, and was an instrumental part of the showtime era in 1980s, winning five NBA championships as a coach and executive. He is the former president and head coach of the Miami Heat of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He has been a head coach in the NBA with seven different teams. Riley has coached teams to five NBA Championships (1982, 1985, 1987, 1988, 2006), two in Los Angeles and three in Miami and appeared in the NBA Finals with five separate teams; losing three others. Riley's Los Angeles Lakers of 1984-85 and Miami Heat of 1999-2000 are two of the four teams in NBA history who won at least 61 games in the regular season during the 1980s and 1990s.[1] Riley's unorthodox coaching approaches and brash persona made him a volatile and highly sought after person for the various coaching jobs that were open after the 1990-91 season. He ultimately signed with the New York Knicks and helped return the moribund team to respectability, winning the Eastern Conference Championship in 1993-94 and going to the NBA Finals, though Riley's personality clashed with veteran players like Patrick Ewing, Charles Oakley, and others. In addition to his coaching abilities, he was popular with the media and helped to generate positive press with his witty insights that captured the imagination of fans. He also played on the team that won the first NBA Championship for New York in 1970. answer: Led Zeppelin were an English rock band formed in London in 1968. The group consisted of guitarist Jimmy Page, singer Robert Plant, bassist and keyboardist John Paul Jones, and drummer John Bonham. After changing their name from the New Yardbirds, the group signed to Atlantic Records and released their eponymous debut album. Led Zeppelin's fourth album, which featured the track "Stairway to Heaven", is among the most popular and influential works in rock music, and it cemented the popularity of the group. Subsequent recording sessions for their follow-up album Physical Graffiti (1975) were disrupted by Bonham's declining health, as he suffered from poor dietary habits, insomnia, and excessive consumption of alcohol. He died of pulmonary asphyxiation on 20 September 1980, after inhaling his own vomit, a result of ingesting 40% alcohol.

answer: Flash Thompson, sometimes called Eugene Thompson, is a fictional supporting anti-hero character of the Marvel Comics universe. topic: Modern liberalism in the United States
answer: Modern liberalism in the United States is the prevailing version of liberalism in the United States and is the primary ideology of the Democratic Party. Modern U.S. liberals are characterized by a set of political beliefs and positions that include the following: a belief in personal liberty, or personal freedom; a belief in government or collective action to provide social justice; a belief in the role of institution, tradition and unity as a means to achieve "the public good"; a belief in equality, equal opportunity, or equal social outcome; and a belief in the "rule of law".

topic: Transformers: Age of Extinction, Transformers: Age of Extinction
answer: Transformers: Age of Extinction is a 2014 American science-fiction action film based on Hasbro's Transformers toyline. It is the fourth installment of the live-action Transformers film series and a sequel to 2011's Dark of the Moon. Directed by Michael Bay, it stars Mark Wahlberg in the lead role, with Stanley Tucci, Joshua Joyce, Titus Welliver, John Goodman, and Ken Watanabe. The film introduces four new protagonists, and features the first major theatrical appearance of the Chevrolet Camaro and the Chevrolet Corvette Stingray in the Transformers film series, as opposed to the traditional models. Taking place four years after the war on Cybertron in Transformers: Dark of the Moon, the film starts with government agency Transformers Reaction Force (TRF) continuing to exterminate all remaining Decepticons. Meanwhile, the Autobots and most of the Decepticons have fled Cybertron and come to Earth in order to hide. It takes place ten years later, in 2017, with a mechanic and his daughter making a major discovery about the history of the Transformers, a secret mission and the threat of a powerful and ancient force.

answer: Richard Ramirez (February 29, 1960 – June 7, 2013) was an American serial killer and rapist. He was dubbed "The Night Stalker". A series of 13 killings, all committed in California, took place in the early months of 1985. The victims were men and women of various ages and backgrounds, and many were stabbed to death. The assailant entered homes at night by way of either unlocked doors or windows. He also strangled and raped some of the victims. At the time of the murders, Ramirez was a 25-year-old self-employed utility worker. He was arrested after a thorough investigation by the Los Angeles Police Department. He was found guilty of 13 counts of murder on September 20, 1989, and received 19 death sentences.

USER:
answer: Ken Russell, CBE, HRGS, (3 March 1927 – 27 November 2011) was an English film director, television director and screenwriter generally classified as a British filmmaker, although he was born in Southampton, England and made the first part of his career in a country of which he was proud. Russell's films in the late 1960s and early 1970s were partly atypical of the British film industry, being lavish, idiosyncratic, and in some instances extremely violently or sexually explicit. He was always ready to experiment with editing, style and narrative structure, and to make non-linear, subjective, multi-view cinematic expression a means of investigating both cinematic techniques and the film's subject matter. He often used shooting techniques that were derived not only from his experimental documentaries but also from cinéma vérité, such as in his documentary A Kew Gardens and the shot in the feature film Altered States where Sally Field is seen by her husband walking on water. His films during these formative phases contained many pop-art style effects including a dream-like narrative structure, direct address (breaking the fourth wall) through voiceover, elliptical and often fragmented editing, shockingly violent or sexual imagery and a juxtaposition of soundtrack styles.

answer: Tequila (Spanish pronunciation: [teˈkila]) is a regional distilled beverage and type of alcoholic beverage made from the blue agave plant, primarily in the area surrounding the city of Tequila, 65 km (40 mi) northwest of Guadalajara, and in the highlands (Los Altos) of the north western Mexican state of Jalisco. Aside from differences in the manufacturing process, tequila is similar to other distilled beverages. The main differences are that tequila must use the Blue agave plant and this must be at least 51% of the drink. To be termed tequila, at least 51% of agave plant must be used in the distilled liquor. Most distilled spirits contain liquor produced for mixing, and so are not produced from 100% of their base substance. Tequila is also the base of a wide variety of mixed drinks, among the best-known is the margarita.

topic: The Lion King, Walt Disney Animation Studios
answer: The Lion King is a 1994 American animated feature film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation. Released in theaters on June 15, 1994, by Walt Disney Pictures, the film is the 32nd Disney animated feature with a story influenced by the biblical parable of the prodigal son and the tragic figure of Hamlet. In the film, a young lion cub named Simba, who is heir to the throne of the Pride Lands, is persuaded to run away from his kingdom. It features a large ensemble of characters that were all voiced by well-known actors. The film features songs written by composer Elton John and lyricist Tim Rice, and several characters are named after or inspired by their songs.

topic: Modern liberalism in the United States
answer: Modern liberalism in the United States is the dominant version of liberalism in the United States. It is characterized by its emphasis on social justice, especially social equity, and the assumption that the role of the government should be expanded in order to enforce this, as well as its support of a mixed economy. It combines fiscal conservatism with social liberalism, and it is distinct from classical liberalism, welfare liberalism and social democratic liberalism.

answer: Enough Project is a non-profit organization based in Washington, D.C. It has partnered with a number of other organizations such as Amnesty International, the Council on Foreign Relations, the International Crisis Group and the Center for Public Integrity. It is led by executive director John Prendergast and co-founded by John Prendergast, Gayle Smith, and Omer Ismail. The project focuses on combating African conflicts that are funded by natural resources, such as diamonds, gold, oil and timber. The conflict in the northeastern region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo is referred to as "Africa's World War". The project was originally named the End of War and Violence Program at the International Crisis Group, before it became independent in 2007. The project uses a multifaceted methodology to combat resource-driven conflict, and its main strategies include advocacy campaigns and investigation of the links among conflict, diamonds and oil.

answer: Ready Player One: A Novel is a 2011, dystopian novel, written by Ernest Cline and published by Random House. answer: Luxembourg (Luxembourgish: Lëtzebourg, French: Luxembourg, German: Luxemburg), officially the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg (Luxembourgish: Groussherzogtum Lëtzebuerg, French: Grand-Duché de Luxembourg, German: Großherzogtum Luxemburg), is a landlocked country in Western Europe. It is one of the smallest sovereign states in Europe, bordered by Belgium to the west, Germany to the north, and France to the south. Luxembourg has two official languages, Luxembourgish and French. It is part of the Schengen Area and the eurozone. The country has a minor coast on the North Sea in the Luxembourg Clif.

answer: Massachusetts ( (listen) or ), officially the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is a state in the New England region of the Northeastern United States. It borders Rhode Island and Connecticut to the south, New York and Vermont to the west, New Hampshire and the Atlantic Ocean to the east, and New Brunswick and the Canadian provinces of Maine and New Brunswick to the north. answer: International Space Station (ISS) is a space station, or a habitable artificial satellite, in low Earth orbit. Its first component launched into orbit in 1998, and the last pressurised module was fitted in 2011. It has been continuously occupied for seventeen years and 151 days as of 11 April 2018, making it the longest-operating, continuously inhabited spacecraft. It is a microgravity and weightlessness research, including experiments in biology, human biology, physical science, and material science. The ISS serves as a microgravity and space environment research testbed in which crew members conduct experiments in biology, human biology, physics, astronomy, meteorology, and other fields. The station is suited for the testing of devices that are experimental and not ready for use on other platforms, such as the Hubble Space Telescope.

answer: Ilkhanate (also spelled as Il-Khanate) was a Mongol khanate established in the mid-13th century. answer: 2013 NBA draft took place on June 27, 2013, at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York. National Basketball Association (NBA) drafts, are held by the National Basketball Association (NBA), and govern proceedings for eligible players who are looking to join the league. Teams must first ensure they are under the league mandated salary cap, which is set at $58.09 million for the 2012–2013 season with a luxury tax. The salary cap ensures that NBA teams will have a similar competitive environment, and stop teams from having an unfair advantage. The draft consisted of two rounds with a total of 60 players taken. The team with the first overall pick was the Phoenix Suns and the team with the ninth and 14th picks chose from the "early-entry" draft class (allowing players to forgo the rest of their collegiate career).

answer: Pink Floyd were an English rock band formed in London in 1965. They originally earned recognition for their psychedelic or space rock music, and, as they evolved, for their progressive rock music. They are known for philosophical lyrics, sonic experimentation, innovative cover art, and elaborate live shows. One of rock music's most successful acts, the group have sold over 250 million records worldwide and 74.5 million in certified units in the United States alone. They were also one of the top-earning musical acts, with an estimated fortune of £476 million. Pink Floyd were inducted into the American, British, Canadian, and French rock and roll hall of fame, and won multiple awards and achieved numerous industry accomplishments. The group was founded by students Syd Barrett, Nick Mason, Roger Waters, and Richard Wright, who first met at London's Regent Street Polytechnic in 1964. The group's first single, "Arnold Layne", was released in 1967. Sometime after the release of the single, guitarist David Gilmour joined to bolster the group's live performances. After the group's second album, A Saucerful of Secrets, Barrett began to experience drug-related mental health problems, and was increasingly erratic in both his behaviour and his contributions to the group. Pink Floyd and Barrett agreed that Barrett would leave the group after the conclusion of their 1967 tour in 1968, with Barrett contributing only one track, "Jugband Blues", to A Saucerful of Secrets, and David Gilmour becoming an official member.

topic: Arabian Peninsula, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates
answer: Arabian Peninsula, also spelled Arabia, in geographers' terms, peninsula of southwestern Asia, comprising the present countries of Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain, and Kuwait. It extends (as an entity, excluding the Sahara, or African, desert to the west) for some 3,000 km (1,900 miles) from the northern 60th parallel to the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea—a distance comparable with that of the Iberian Peninsula in Europe—and varies in width from a maximum of some 2,000 km (1,600 miles) to a minimum of less than 100 km (60 miles). The area of the Arabian Peninsula is generally given as some 3,200,000 square km (1,250,000 square miles), a figure arrived at by adding the land areas of all the Arab countries together, or as a minimum of some 2,100,000 square km (850,000 square miles), if the coastal areas are counted separately. The highest point on the peninsula is Mount Al-Nūr on Yemen's Jabal al-Nūr (Mountains of Light) at about 3,760 m (12,335 feet), roughly comparable with western Europe's highest point, the 4,807-metre (15,771-foot) Mont Blanc. The peninsula has a surface area that is almost four times as large as that of France.

answer: Lymphoma is a type of cancer in which lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell, behave anomalously, dividing uncontrollably, and disrupting life-critical body functions. The abnormal behavior is not only limited to the division of the lymphocytes but also the over-production of the immunoglobulins. When there is over-production of the immunoglobulins, then the body is considered to have an immunodeficiency, in which case the immunodeficiency could be chronic, resulting in an auto-immune disease.

answer: Measles, also known as rubeola, is an infectious disease caused by the measles virus. Symptoms normally appear 7–14 days after exposure and usually last 1–2 weeks. Signs and symptoms typically include a fever, cough, runny nose, sore throat, and a characteristic maculopapular skin rash. It is spread by droplets in the air that have been breathed out or coughed out by an infected person. Approximately one-quarter of measles cases are complicated by diarrhea and/or pneumonia. As of 2017, there is no established treatment for measles; supportive care is usually only needed in complicated cases.

USER:
answer: Caracazo is a popular name used by Venezuelans and foreigners to refer to the events of February and March 1989, one of the most violent and destructive wave of riots of the 20th century in Venezuela. Most of the damage happened in three days, the beginning of the week of February 27, 1989, after the government increased the cost of gasoline and public transportation fares. The Caracazo left an immeasurable impact on Venezuelan society. Many Venezuelans who lived through the Caracazo saw themselves as victims of a new social and political elite who exploited them for political and economic reasons. Many Venezuelans now feel that the country was unjustly used as a foreign entity’s instrument to exploit people and resources. Some believe that the Caracazo contributed to the rise of Hugo Chávez and his administration.

answer: Ballet Shoes (film) is a 2007 British television film adaptation of the novel of the same name by Noel Streatfeild, produced by Granada Productions and WGBH-Boston. It was first broadcast on 26 December 2007 on BBC One, and later broadcast on 2 February 2008 on PBS. 68 years after its source novel was published, and 43½ years after the last adaptation was broadcast, the telefilm was seen by a viewing audience of 10.5 million, and received praise from viewers and critics alike for its adaption and portrayal of an often difficult to follow period in history.[1] The film was produced by Sandra Jobling, the daughter of the book's original illustrator, Ruth Gervis. The score for this mini-series was composed by Stephen Warbeck, best known for his score for the Shakespeare In Love soundtrack and his work with Aardman Animations on a number of films.

topic: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
answer: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a 2016 American superhero film, serving as a follow-up to 2013's Man of Steel and intended to be the first installment in the DC Comics' shared universe films. Directed by Zack Snyder, the film stars Ben Affleck, Henry Cavill, Amy Adams, Jesse Eisenberg, Diane Lane, Laurence Fishburne, Jeremy Irons and Holly Hunter. It features the DC Comics characters Superman, Batman, and Wonder Woman in its main plot, along with other DC characters such as Lex Luthor, Doomsday, and Alfred, as well as several new characters created for the film.

answer: Central America is the central and most southerly group of states in the Americas. It is found between the Rocky Mountains and the Pacific Ocean. A land bridge connects the region to North America, but the land that is now America was formerly connected to South America via the Panamanian isthmus. Central America consists of Belize, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama. It is bordered to the northwest by Chiriquí, a territory of Panama that is administered de facto by Costa Rica.

topic: The Waterboy, Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)
answer: The Waterboy is a 1998 American sports comedy film directed by Frank Coraci in his directorial debut, starring Adam Sandler, Kathy Bates, Fairuza Balk, Henry Winkler, Jerry Reed, Larry Gilliard, Jr., Blake Clark, Peter Dante, and Jonathan Loughran (the latter of whom plays the title character). It was the first film produced by Sandler's production company, Hosedog Productions. The film was released in the United States on November 6, 1998, and was a commercial success, grossing over $188 million and becoming the 10th-highest-grossing film of 1998. Although the film received negative reviews from critics, it was nominated for five Razzies with Sandler winning his only Worst Actor award. However, the film was a success with the NFL, which signed the "Pardon My Dust!!" trademark logo to NFL licenses worldwide.

answer: Evil Queen (Disney) is a fictional character and the main antagonist of the Disney animated feature film, Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937), as well as other related media. answer: The Bourne Supremacy (film) is a 2004 American-German action spy thriller film. Though it is not based on a specific Robert Ludlum novel, the film is a sequel to the 2002 film The Bourne Identity after the character Jason Bourne from the Bourne trilogy novels by Ludlum. Paul Greengrass returned as director, Bourne being portrayed again by Matt Damon, and Joan Allen, Brian Cox and Julia Stiles reprising their roles as, respectively, Pamela Landy, Ward Abbott and Nicky Parsons. The film begins a few years after the end of the first film and Bourne continues to learn who he really is, as he and Marie relocate in order to evade further Bourne identity disclosure. This sequel also reveals his family's tie to CIA Deputy Director Hiram Codd (John Bedford Lloyd) and Operation Treadstone, the genesis of the Bourne identity.

answer: Oliver Reed (13 February 1938 – 2 May 1999) was an English film actor. He was known for his leading-man roles; in particular for his portrayal of Athos in the 1970 film adaptation of The Three Musketeers and the film sequels. Reed appeared in 70 films in his career and also directed two of them. He was described by the UK newspaper The Sun as "a hellraiser"  who was "famed for his drinking". He was often referred to as "mad", "tyrannical", and "mysterious". He once boasted that he had slept with 1,000 women and had beaten up hundreds of men. While he was admired by a number of film legends such as John Hurt, Peter O'Toole, and Richard Harris. Others, including Michael Winner and Malcolm McDowell, were repulsed by Reed's hell-raising.

answer: Minnesota Vikings is an American football team based in Minneapolis. Established in 1961, the team is the newest in a sport that had its first season in 1869. answer: Caspian Sea is the largest enclosed inland body of water on Earth by area with a surface area of 371,000 km² (143,200 sq mi). It is an inland sea of ​​eastern Europe and central Asia, with a North-South orientation, in the so-called interior drainage basin of Central Asia, which does not reach any ocean; It is often considered as an intermediate sea of ​​Europe and Asia or as the largest lake in the world. It has an immense coastline of 7,000 km (4,300 mi). It is bordered to the north by Russia, to the west by Iran, to the east by Afghanistan and Turkmenistan, and to the south by the Karakum Desert and Iran. The Kazakh name is Каспий теңізі, the Persian name is دریاچه خزر دریا / دریای مازندران (Persian) or دریاچه مازندران / دریای مازندران (more colloquial and modern); the Russian name is Каспīйское море / Каспийское море (Kaspiyskoye more); and the Turkish name is Hazar Denizi (meaning "The sea of the thousand islands"). It is rich in fish and in aquatic mammals, It is a major source of sturgeon, which produces caviar. At times, oil and gas fields have been discovered in the basin. This region is situated above an ancient underground oil field; the existence of oil was known since antiquity, where Herodotus mentioned the Caspian oil in his Histories. (484–425 BC). Almost all the coastal towns with oil extracted in the 19th and 20th century, but only four companies now produce crude oil and natural gas there.

answer: Beautiful (Christina Aguilera song) The most-played version of "Beautiful" is a dance mix, at a running time of 3:36, which features the instrumental of Scooch's 2000 single "Four Months, Two Weeks and Two Days" in its full length version. "Beautiful" was released as an EP on June 18, 2003, by RCA Records. The promo disc contains five track versions of the "Beautiful" song: "Beautiful", "Beautiful" [Instrumental], "Beautiful" [Dance Mix], "Beautiful" [A Capella], and "Beautiful" [Video Mix]. The song was not released as a single, since according to Aguilera, the song is just a "thank you" to her fans. Scooch's version was released as the sixth and final single from Four Months, Two Weeks and Two Days (2000) on October 13, 2000. In the US, Scooch's version was never released as a single and their version of "Beautiful" is a B-side to their single "For Sure". However, in some countries Scooch's version was released as a maxi single, just like Aguilera's version. A UK promo single was released on August 27, 2001. In Australia, a 12" limited-edition promo single was released, which features "The Stomp (Mixed)". In addition to Scooch's original version and the "Extended Club Mix", there is also an "Extended Alternative Mix", the "Radio Mix", the "Radio Cut Down", the "Video Edit" and the "Radio Edit".

answer: Super Nintendo Entertainment System's design was influenced by Hiroshi Yamauchi's rationale that the hardware needed to become more powerful in order to stay ahead of the competition. Yamauchi was initially reluctant to ask his engineers to design a new console as he believed that an obsolescence cycle should be longer. Yamauchi eventually concluded that unless Nintendo were able to make the same games better than the competition, the company could not survive. The system was also designed to be region free.

answer: John Wayne Gacy, Jr. (March 17, 1942 – May 10, 1994) was an American serial killer and rapist, also known as the Killer Clown, who was convicted of the rape and murder of at least 33 teenage boys and young men in Chicago between 1972 and 1978. All of Gacy's known victims were buried in a series of unmarked graves he dug in the crawlspace of his house; 29 of the bodies and three other victims whose blood Gacy had used to paint were discovered when police tracked Gacy down and searched his house on December 12, 1978. 27 of the bodies were found in their individual graves on his property; 4 others were discovered in unmarked burial sites elsewhere. Almost all of Gacy's known victims went missing between September 1977 and December 1978, although three of the victims known to have been killed by Gacy were reported missing before September 1977, and one victim vanished sometime after December 1978.

Bush (born George Herbert Walker Bush; July 6, 1924) is an American politician and businessman who was the 43rd president of the United States from 1989 to 1993 and the 46th vice president from 1981 to 1989. He is the second person to have served as both, after John Adams. answer: United States of America is a federal republic consisting of 50 states and a federal district. The 48 contiguous states and the federal district of Washington, D.C. are situated in North America between Canada and Mexico. The state of Alaska is in northwestern North America, west of Canada and east of Russia across the Bering Strait, and the state of Hawaii is in the North Pacific. The United States is the third- or fourth-largest nation in total area (land and water), ranking behind Russia and just smaller than Canada. The rank order of those three changes depending on how two non-separate Arctic segments are counted for Canada and Russia. The U.S.'s size is a result of the 1777 acquisition of the Northwest Territories from Great Britain and the 1803 Louisiana Purchase from France, plus Alaska (Russia). The modern United States was formed in 1789, following a war between states in the 1780s, when delegates of the Thirteen Colonies met in what became known as the Second Continental Congress.

answer: Dayton Agreement in 1995 was the first signed agreement in the Yugoslav Wars conflict. In the agreement, the warring parties agreed to unite Bosnia and Herzegovina with a devolved central government. answer: Rain Man is a 1988 American comedy-drama film written by Barry Morrow and Ronald Bass and directed by Barry Levinson. answer: Ecuador is a representative democratic republic in northwestern South America, bordered by Colombia on the north, by Peru on the east and south, and by the Pacific Ocean on the west. Ecuador also includes the Galápagos Islands in the Pacific, about 1,000 kilometers (620 mi) west of the mainland. What is now Ecuador was part of the northern Inca Empire until the Spanish defeated the Incas in 1533. Ecuador is very ethnically diverse, and today the largest ethnic group is the Mestizos, who account for 74% of the current population.

answer: Havoc (2005 film) is a drama film that follows the life of Allison, a wealthy girl whose life falls apart when her boyfriend is arrested for dealing drugs. In an attempt to get money to help him get out, she gets roped into doing undercover work for Detective Cole- he wants her to get close to a drug dealer and she thinks she'll be able to help her boyfriend. Allison discovers that the drug dealer is a young man named Reese; she has already seen him at nightclubs, and on the night they meet, she is entranced by his personality, which contrasts from most of her old-money friends. answer: The Hunger Games (film) is a 2012 American film directed by Gary Ross based on the novel The Hunger Games by Suzanne Collins. topic: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song)
answer: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song) is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars for his debut studio album, Doo-Wops & Hooligans (2010). It was written by: Bruno Mars and Phil Lawrence, it was produced by The Smeezingtons, with additional production by Mars, and co-produced by Robert "Zo" Glassman. answer: Algeria (/ældrd/; Arabic: الجزائر‎, al-Jazāʾir, Berber: ⵍⵡⵍⵏⴰⵢⵔ, Leɛar; French: Algérie), officially the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria, is a North African country on the Mediterranean coast. Its capital and most populous city is Algiers, located in the country's far north. With an area of 2,386,700 square kilometres (920,900 sq mi), Algeria is the tenth-largest country in the world, and the largest in Africa. The country is bordered to the northeast by Tunisia, to the east by Libya, to the southeast by Niger, to the southwest by Mali, to the west by Mauritania, and to the northwest by Morocco. The country's name derives from the city of Algiers.

answer: The Blacklist (TV series) The Blacklist is an American crime drama thriller television series that premiered on NBC on September 23, 2013. answer: Kate Nash (born 6 July 1987) is an English singer, songwriter, and musician. After dropping out of sixth form college, she had a series of jobs, including working at an American clothing store, a cinema, a pub, a real estate agent and, for a time, on a market stall at Spitalfields, London, selling retro lampshades. She performed in and organised acoustic nights at numerous east London venues, often playing two or three sets a night on the same evening. She taught herself the guitar with the aim of being able to perform on her own at open-mic nights, but instead of rehearsing, she wrote her first ever song, "Carried Away", and performed it at the open-mic night at The Spittalfields Tavern in Spitalfields. The bar manager of The Good Ship, Mark Dineen had heard of Nash and contacted her.

answer: Benin (/bəˈnɪn/ ( listen); French: Bénin), officially the Republic of Bénin (French: République du Bénin), formerly Dahomey, is a country in West Africa. answer: Malala Yousafzai (Pashto: /ˈmɛləla ˈjussɪfzaiː/) (born 12 July 1997) is a Pakistani activist for female education and the youngest Nobel Prize laureate. Yousafzai was born in Mingora, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Yousafzai was educationally activist in a very young age in 2008 by blogging for the BBC. In early 2009, after the Taliban issued a death threat against her, she began to write under a pseudonym on her own Urdan and English blog. Yousafzai was attacked on her 16th birthday and was injured in her right eye. 2013 she was nominated for the World Children's Prize, won the European Union's Sakharov Prize for "Freedom of Thought". In October 2018, Yousafzai called to help the 1.33 lakh Rohingyas of Myanmar.

answer: Odyssey is the fifth studio album by American singer-songwriter Carly Rae Jepsen, released on February 15, 2018 through School Boy Records and Interscope Records. Lyrically, the record is centered around the theme of love and heartbreak, while having odes to her own sexuality as a bi woman, as well as odes to mental health and finding the power within to love one's self. "Never Wanted to Cry" and "The Sound" feature lyrics in French.

topic: Back to the Future Part II
answer: Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 American science fiction film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Zemeckis and Bob Gale. It is the sequel to the 1985 film Back to the Future and the second installment of the Back to the Future trilogy and is the time travel comedy film to have its sequel made first. Though released in 1989, the story's setting is October 26, 1985, when Marty McFly, who has just resolved the fates of his eccentric scientist friend, Dr. Emmett Brown, and (defeating) his nemesis from 1955, Biff Tannen, he discovers that the personal crisis he's trying to avert by time-traveling to 1985 has already happened. The world has changed beyond recognition and he must urgently find a way back to 1985 to repair the time-space continuum so that his family, and the universe, survives.

answer: Halle Berry (born August 14, 1966) is an American actress. Berry won an Academy Award for Best Actress in 2002 for her performance in the romantic drama film Monster's Ball (2001). topic: Liev Schreiber, Golden Globe Awards, Golden Globe Awards
answer: Liev Schreiber (born October 4, 1967) is an American actor and director. He starred as Orlando onstage in a production of Shakespeare's As You Like It for director Adrian Lester at the American Shakespeare Theatre in January 2005. He has performed several times in a wide variety of roles on Broadway, such as Viola in Twelfth Night, Philip in Talking about Love, and Leon Trotsky in the Tony nominated revival of A Marriage of Convenience, directed by his friend, director John Tillinger. He made his Broadway debut playing the title role in Hamlet, in the Shakespeare in the Park production that opened the newly reconstructed Shakespearean Dream, in August 2005, at the New York Shakespeare Festival in Central Park. He portrayed Talk Show Host on Broadway in the April 2013 premiere of Rodney Ackland's Absurd Person Singular, alongside Claire Danes, and Brian Avers. In 2009, Schreiber hosted the annual Tony Awards ceremony with co-host and actress, Catherine Zeta-Jones. The New York Times wrote of his performance "Liev Schreiber, who cohosted with Tony award-winning actress Catherine Zeta-Jones, proved himself a deft and nimble host. With wit and charm, Mr. Schreiber led the show and performed double duty, returning to the stage to act in the Broadway smash Billy Elliot.

answer: Ice hockey is a team sport played on ice in which two teams of skaters use sticks and shovels to direct a hard rubber puck around the ice using sticks with curved blades. It is played using six or five players per side: one goalie, four defensemen, and six or five forwards. Five players from each team skate up and down the ice at the same time, trying to take the puck and score a goal against the opposing team, using their sticks to knock the puck around and pass it to other players. The game is played on ice arenas known as rinks, where the ice is usually kept frozen by refrigerating the ice surface.

USER:
answer: Kaminey is a 2009 Indian action film directed by Vishal Bhardwaj and starring Shahid Kapoor in the title role alongside Priyanka Chopra, with whom he was last seen in the 2006 romantic comedy film Omkara. The film's plot concerns Charlie, a lonesome protagonist who is born with twin brother separated in their birth. One with a handicap on the left ear and is thus speech impaired (charlie, played by Shahid kapoor) and the other a clever criminal (Guddu, played by Shahid kapoor). The film was produced by Ronnie Screwvala through UTV Motion Pictures. The film was scheduled for release on 14 August 2009, India's Independence Day, despite the fact that two similarly themed films from the Hindi film industry were set to release on the same date. It was originally scheduled for release on 18 September 2009, but was preponed to 14 August 2009.

topic: Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago), Chicago
answer: Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago) (MSI) is a museum in Chicago, Illinois, dedicated to the areas of industry, science, and technology. It was originally formed from the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition. Originally known as the Columbian Museum of Chicago, it was renamed the Field Museum was relocated to a larger building in 1920. The MSI is the largest science museum in the Western Hemisphere and its oldest and arguably largest science museum in the world.

topic: The New Adventures of Old Christine
answer: The New Adventures of Old Christine (originally called The New Adventures of Old Christine of Old Christine until being re-titled for its second season) is an American sitcom television series, originally broadcast on CBS. The series stars Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Clark Gregg as a divorced mother and father who are now living apart, and often in emotional and humorous conflict with one another. It reran on Lifetime (2011–12), Wednesday nights at 10:30pm ET, on the ABC syndicated market, 7, on ION, 9 and later 9:30, on A&E 7:30 and 10:00 PM EST) on cable networks (USA, A&E), as well syndicated locally on some networks and independent stations (sometimes daytime, at the 7 pm EST hour) in the United States, and on the Hallmark Channel in 2017 and 2018.

answer: Wyatt Earp (March 19, 1848 – January 13, 1929) was an American deputy US marshal in the American Old West who worked in various Western cattle-boom towns and who was one of the principle figures in the events leading up to and following the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral, alongside his comrades at arms, the Earp brothers and Doc Holliday. He is often regarded by historians as the central man in the gunfight. After the gunfight, he went on to have an eventful life and 40-year career as a "gambler, frontier constable, mining share speculator, referee of a world heavyweight boxing match, entrepreneur, and capitalist" according to Ron Slate. Wyatt did not have many accomplishments. He was known for having killed many people and for having survived in one of the most lawless towns in the West. He is often regarded as the fastest gun of the wild west for having supposedly shot down 20 men dead or drowning. He was not only feared and respected in the Old West but famous in the media for being the "brave" gunslinger of the West. He was regarded as one of the most effective and famous sheriffs in America at the period of the wild wild west before modern law enforcement, crime scene investigation, and forensic sciences were developed.

He previously served as the 33rd Governor of California from 1967 to 1975 and prior to that as the 55th Vice President of the United States from 1973 to 1974. A Republican, he was a Hollywood actor and union leader before being elected to public office. He successfully deregulated business and increased military spending, as well as lowering taxes for the wealthy—his legacy has been fiercely debated by conservatives as he was the face of modern conservatism, while some conservatives have argued he is not an "real conservative."

USER:
answer: Boot Monument is a tall memorial obelisk in Bury St Edmunds in the English county of Suffolk. It commemorates the last English commander at the Battle of Agincourt during the Hundred Years' War: Sir William Philip Sir William Philip, a knight and leader of the Suffolk contingent at Agincourt. The monument is thought to be a unique commemorative structure because it is one of the only surviving public monuments to an English casualty from the war, and the only monument dedicated to a member of the English military that took part in the conflict. In its original form, the monument included a 23 feet (7.0 m) high structure that was topped by the stone effigy of a knight, which now sits beneath the monument. The base of the monument is engraved with Sir William Philip's emblems: a yew tree and an ostrich feather—the emblems of the Beaufort family—suggesting the knight's family origins, and a boot, from which the monument gets its name.

answer: Animal Farm is a dystopian novella by ‎George Orwell. The original title was Animal Farm: A Fairy Story, but the subtitle was dropped by US publishers, so that the 1946 first American edition bore on its title page the title Animal Farm. The novel, which chronicles an attempted Communist revolution at a collective farm in England, was published in London by Martin Secker and Lottie Lubbock in 1945, but was not published in the United States until August 1946, after its success in Britain. It reached a broad international audience, with "the number of translations already done or in preparation, the sales already accomplished or to be expected, and the extent of impassioned argument which the book has called forth. No novel published this year has had the impact of Animal Farm."

answer: Russia (Russian: Росси́я, tr. Rossiya, IPA: ), federation, and a country in Eurasia. At 17,125,200 square kilometres (6,612,100 sq mi), it is either the largest country in the world or one of the largest. It is the ninth most populous country, with 144.5 million people at the end of October 2016. It is a semi-presidential constitutional republic. Moscow is the capital and the largest city. Extending across the entirety of Northern Asia and much of Eastern Europe, Russia spans eleven time zones and has had more than 25 million square kilometres (9.7 million square miles) of territory. It is bordered by Norway and Finland to the west, and the Baltic States, Poland, and Ukraine to the south. Russia's extensive borders include seacoasts along the Arctic, Pacific, and in the west, a short coastline at the Sea of Austria, adjacent to the Mediterranean Sea. The country is one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.

answer: J. J. Cale (December 5, 1938 – July 26, 2013) was an American guitarist, singer, songwriter, and record producer. Though he deliberately avoided publicity to the point of shunning not only fame but also fortune, Cale is regarded as one of the most significant figures in the roots rock movement and credited as the primary originator of the Tulsa Sound, a loose form of rock music with a Native American (courtesy to the Choctaw Cale's ancestry) influence that relies on simple, straightforward, and centric to blues, country, and early rock and roll styles of that music. Cale's vocal style (with a strong, resonant voice in baritone range) has been described as a "laconic" and "plain" style similar to that of his music, and has been compared to Leonard Cohen, Don Van Vliet (in Captain Beefheart), and John Fogerty.

answer: Look at My Dab is an expression of surprise and approval said when somebody does something exceptionally well. The phrase was created in the mid-2010s and has gained popularity after being used during the 2016 election cycle. The expression was popularised on Tumblr in 2016, in a meme format featuring an animated image of Hillary Clinton making a similar gesture. It is often used as a counter-reply to "Electoral College", a reference to how the candidate won the majority of votes but not the electoral vote.

topic: Charles, Prince of Wales, George VI
answer: Charles was the eldest son of King Louis XIV of France and his primary wife, the infanta Maria Theresa of Spain. His official titles were Duke of Berry (1661–1686), Duke of Alençon (1672–1686), Duke of Château-d'Oro (1665–1670), Duke of Anjou (1669–1670), Duke of Normandy (1669–1670), and Duke of Guise (1670–1686).

USER:
answer: Performance (film) Performance, also known as Performance - The Film, is a British musical drama film directed by Donald Cammell and Nicolas Roeg, written by Cammell and starring Mick Jagger of the Rolling Stones, James Fox, and Vanessa Redgrave. It was released in 1970 and was a product of the collaboration between Donald Cammell and Nicolas Roeg. Performance can be viewed as an attempt to explore the border between fantasy and reality in the mind. Critic Roger Ebert was disturbed by the film: "Performance is a difficult film, and not simply because it's a poor copy of Fellini... No, the problem is that the movie takes itself so seriously. It's a bad mistake to build a psychedelic picture around such pedestrian material as gangsters, porn stars and drug addicts, and to fall head over heels into the fantasies of the stoned mind, and to make Mick Jagger the symbol of our incipient apocalypse just because he had a haircut and sold a few records to young people who went on to make the world a slightly more interesting place to live in. If Performance had been made about something serious, something real, it might have had more meaning".
